fields.description:
I have found an issue whereby an instance migration is stuck as pending (a separate issue to be linked) In order to try to stop the migration I tried to terminate the instance only to find that that is not possible while an instance is pending migration.

{code}
2015-06-29 21:28:09 ERROR | java.lang.RuntimeException: Cannot terminate an instance which is currently migrating: i-9ff43b20 preparing 10.111.5.157->10.111.1.67
{code}

Steps:
# setup cloud with 2 nodes
# run an instance
# migrate the instance...it would be nice to be able to cancel and rollback a migration

topology:
\[CLC CC SC WS\]
\[UFS\]
\[NC\]
\[NC\]
fields.summary: Raise a clear error why actions cannot be performed due to migration in progress.

comments.body: This is about raising a clear error why actions cannot be performed due to migration in progress.
[~tony] RuntimeException is a bit generic, but what other information would you like to see in the error message when this occurs?

[~jhalterman], honestly this was so long ago I don't know what I was thinking. Maybe it was that the terminate call succeeded or did not complain and I had to go to the log to determine what happened.

[~tony] So is there anything you'd still like to see done for this? If requesting a terminate via the CLI, perhaps the error message regarding migration could be presented there if the CLC reports it? What do you think?
[~jhalterman] I think that sounds very reasonable.

Presently, the terminateInstances implementation almost always returns a result when an instance cannot be terminated instead of throwing. This is likely due to an attempt to terminate any instances possible, but the result is that the client doesn't know if an instance termination was successful or not.

Cross-checking with EC2, when attempting to terminate an instance that is protected along with one that is not, EC2 returns OperationNotPermitted and does not terminate either instance.

Verification needed for autoscaling, cloudformation, cloudwatch.

QA verification notes from Steve:

[17:00:11]  <sjones4>	so setting the desired capacity of a group to 0 after starting migration for an autoscaling instance
[17:00:28]  <sjones4>	deleting a cloudformation stack with an instance as it is being migrated
[17:00:50]  <sjones4>	triggering a cloudwatch alarm to delete an instance as it is being migrated
[17:01:00]  <sjones4>	that last one might be tricky

Re: trigging an alarm, we should be able to trigger an alarm action by setting the state to ALARM via the SetAlarmState API: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/APIReference/API_SetAlarmState.html

New output after this change:

$ euca-terminate-instances i-36fa497d
euca-terminate-instances: error (OperationNotPermitted): Cannot terminate an instance which is currently migrating: i-36fa497d preparing
$ euca-terminate-instances i-36fa497d
euca-terminate-instances: error (OperationNotPermitted): Cannot terminate an instance which is currently migrating: i-36fa497d migrating 10.111.5.104->10.111.5.95

Would the error output be the same for all accounts or is that a special case for the cloud administrator? As node details may not be appropriate for all users, we may want to keep the error messages more general. If a cloud administrator wanted to see more details they could check the instances migration related tags.

[~sjones] I ran this as an admin, but I assume it would be the same for any account that could perform a migration. Wouldn't only admins be able to perform migrations though? If not, where would be the appropriate place to put controls on the error output - in the service implementation itself?

[~jhalterman], a cloud administrator would be migrating instances, but any user could be terminating an instance that is being migrated. My preference would be to have a general error message in all cases, i.e. not including node details. If we have to have user specific errors then the service would handle that.

Attempts to terminate a migrating instance now return OperationNotPermitted. Steve suggested verifying how this might interact attempts to terminate an instance in other services (which I've already done some of), such as via an autoscaling group, a cloud formation stack, and a cloudwatch alarm. See this comment for a bit more:

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-11044?focusedCommentId=103793&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-103793
[~jhalterman] let's not show node IPs to regular users.

Verified. Proper error message is returned if terminate instance is not possible.

{code}
[root@a-02-l ~]# euca-describe-instances i-4e765ec6
RESERVATION	r-9ca5fe2f	000245275233	default
INSTANCE	i-4e765ec6	emi-fe6039ea	euca-10-116-197-83.eucalyptus.scale-01-01-02.scale1.qa2.eucalyptus-systems.com	euca-172-31-15-175.eucalyptus.internal	runningsshlogin	0		m1.small	2016-07-01T06:30:14.590Z	one				monitoring-disabled	10.116.197.83	172.31.15.175	vpc-08c55632	subnet-ec31a8b9	instance-store					hvm			sg-a2b6e7c7				x86_64
NETWORKINTERFACE	eni-f2d972f4	subnet-ec31a8b9	vpc-08c55632	000245275233	in-use	172.31.15.175	euca-172-31-15-175.eucalyptus.internal	true
ATTACHMENT	eni-attach-6ed9e666	0	attached	2016-07-01T06:30:14.596Z	true
ASSOCIATION	10.116.197.83		172.31.15.175
GROUP	sg-a2b6e7c7	default
PRIVATEIPADDRESS	172.31.15.175	euca-172-31-15-175.eucalyptus.internal	primary
TAG	instance	i-4e765ec6	euca:node	10.112.10.63
TAG	instance	i-4e765ec6	euca:node:migration:destination	10.112.10.47
TAG	instance	i-4e765ec6	euca:node:migration:source	10.112.10.63
TAG	instance	i-4e765ec6	euca:node:migration:state	migrating

[root@a-02-l ~]# euca-terminate-instances i-4e765ec6
euca-terminate-instances: error (OperationNotPermitted): Cannot terminate an instance which is currently migrating: i-4e765ec6
{code}
